title: Product Model Products and policy Lines
sourceFile: In_policy_17_Product Model Products and policy Lines.pptx

slides.title: Introduction to Product Model Specialization
slides.notes: Welcome to the specialization phase of our PolicyCenter training. Today, we're diving into the specifics of the product model, focusing on products and policy lines. This is crucial for understanding how PolicyCenter structures insurance offerings.
slides.narration: Welcome to our deep dive into the world of Guidewire PolicyCenter's product model. In this session, we'll explore how products and policy lines work together to form the backbone of insurance offerings. Understanding these concepts is key to leveraging PolicyCenter's full potential. Let's get started by examining the foundational elements of the product model.
slides.ocrText: Product Model: Products and Policy Lines

slides.title: Understanding the Product Model
slides.notes: The product model is what defines the parameters for assessing risks and drives the interface of PolicyCenter. It's essential for shaping how insurance products are offered and managed.
slides.narration: The product model is fundamental to PolicyCenter, defining the parameters for risk assessment and shaping the interface. This model is driven by business requirements, making it a vital component in tailoring insurance products to meet market needs. Let's explore how these elements interact within PolicyCenter.
slides.ocrText:
Lesson
objectives * Define what a “product” is in terms of

PolicyCenter and the product model

* Describe where a Policy Line fits in the
product model

• List three important questions to ask when
designing a product

slides.title: Components of the Product Model
slides.notes: Explore the components that make up the product model, including entities and relationships that form the structure of insurance products.
slides.narration: Diving deeper, the product model comprises various components, each playing a crucial role in structuring insurance products. These include entities and their relationships, which form the backbone of PolicyCenter's offerings. Understanding these elements is essential for effective configuration and customization.

slides.title: Generalized Object Model
slides.notes: The generalized object model provides an overview of how entities in the product model are structured and related.
slides.narration: Here, we have a look at the generalized object model, which provides a high-level overview of how entities within the product model are structured and interrelated. This structure is pivotal in defining the relationships and interactions between various components of an insurance product.
slides.ocrText:
| Review: the product model Gi

• The product model provides the framework to define products in PolicyCenter
• The product model is where risk is defined for the business
• The product model includes the lines of business, coverages, and coverage terms

• The product model is easy to configure using the Product Designer tool

slides.title: Review: The Product Model
slides.originalNotes:
Review: the product model
The product model is the Zbackbone" of PolicyCenter and where the parameters for assessing risk that an insurer covers are defined. The product model also drives the look and feel of PolicyCenter. Your business requirements are what motivate the design of the product model. The diagram in this slide is the generalized object model for the product model. In this lesson, you will learn more about the role of a Policy Line and how it becomes part of a product.

In this lesson, you will learn more about the role of a Policy Line and how it becomes part of a product.
slides.narration: The product model serves as the backbone of PolicyCenter by defining the parameters for risk assessment and driving the user interface. It's shaped by business requirements, ensuring that the system aligns with market needs. Throughout this lesson, we'll focus on how policy lines integrate into this model.

slides.title: Focus: Products and the Policy Line
slides.originalNotes:
Focus: Products and the Policy Line
A policy line is not the same as a product. A product is set up in the product model that includes a specific line of business (a Policy Line). It is possible to have multiple lines of business within a single product.
slides.notes:
Focus: Products and the Policy Line
A policy line is not the same as a product. A product is set up in the product model that includes a specific line of business (a Policy Line). It is possible to have multiple lines of business within a single product.
slides.narration: Now, it's important to distinguish between products and policy lines. A product setup involves specific lines of business, with the flexibility to include multiple lines within a single product. This distinction is crucial for configuring comprehensive insurance offerings.

slides.title: Product and PolicyLine Pattern Relationship
slides.originalNotes:
Product and PolicyLine pattern relationship
A single product (such as Commercial Package) can have multiple policy line patterns. For example, in the base configuration, there is a Commercial Package Policy available. It consists of General Liability and Commercial Property (required by most carriers usually), and Inland Marine policy.
slides.notes:
Product and PolicyLine pattern relationship
A single product (such as Commercial Package) can have multiple policy line patterns. For example, in the base configuration, there is a Commercial Package Policy available. It consists of General Liability and Commercial Property (required by most carriers usually), and Inland Marine policy.
slides.narration: Let's explore the relationship between products and policy line patterns. A single product, like a Commercial Package Policy, can encompass multiple policy line patterns, such as General Liability and Commercial Property. This modular approach allows for adaptable and comprehensive product offerings.

slides.title: Flexibility and Reuse
slides.originalNotes:
Flexibility and reuse
Multiple products can incorporate a single pattern, such as General Liability. In this example, both a General Liability product and a Commercial Package product have incorporated a General Liability policy line pattern. From a configuration standpoint, portability among policy lines makes creating products easier.
slides.notes:
Flexibility and reuse
Multiple products can incorporate a single pattern, such as General Liability. In this example, both a General Liability product and a Commercial Package product have incorporated a General Liability policy line pattern. From a configuration standpoint, portability among policy lines makes creating products easier.
slides.narration: One of PolicyCenter's strengths is its flexibility and reuse. A single pattern can be used across multiple products, improving configurability and simplifying product creation. For instance, a General Liability pattern can be shared between standalone and packaged products, streamlining development.

slides.title: Policy Lines
slides.originalNotes:
Policy Lines
Developers refer to the Policy Line as the PolicyLine pattern. Developers use the pattern to create Policy Line instances and also define a code and name the Policy Line. They also select the Policy Line subtype which they created in the data model. Policy Lines also require at least one coverage currency. All four of these properties appear in the Product Designer tool. Advanced business analysts also could define some of these details.

Each policy line pattern specifies set of:
Coverage pattems
Categories for Coverages,
Conditions and Exclusions
Modifiers
slides.notes:
Policy Lines
Developers refer to the Policy Line as the PolicyLine pattern. Developers use the pattern to create Policy Line instances and also define a code and name the Policy Line. They also select the Policy Line subtype which they created in the data model. Policy Lines also require at least one coverage currency. All four of these properties appear in the Product Designer tool. Advanced business analysts also could define some of these details.

Each policy line pattern specifies set of:
Coverage pattems
Categories for Coverages,
Conditions and Exclusions
Modifiers
slides.narration: Policy lines, or PolicyLine patterns, are foundational elements in defining insurance products. They include properties such as code, name, subtype, and coverage currency, all configured in the Product Designer. These lines dictate coverages, conditions, exclusions, and modifiers, making them crucial for product customization.
slides.ocrText:
| Policy Lines G

• A Policy Line includes is a set of "legal and
binding" information about the product.
Examples include:

* Information about what exposures can be
covered on the policy

* Information about what coverages are available
on the policy

• Products must have an associated Policy
Line

slides.title: PolicyLine Subtypes
slides.originalNotes:
PolicyLine subtypes
For developers, it is important to know that when PolicyCenter creates a new policy from policy line patterns like the b,vo examples shown here, PolicyCenter needs to know which subtype within the PolicyLine entity to use for the policy instance. PolicyCenter ties patterns to the policy line subtype.
slides.notes:
PolicyLine subtypes
For developers, it is important to know that when PolicyCenter creates a new policy from policy line patterns like the b,vo examples shown here, PolicyCenter needs to know which subtype within the PolicyLine entity to use for the policy instance. PolicyCenter ties patterns to the policy line subtype.
slides.narration: When creating a new policy, PolicyCenter relies on subtypes to define specific policy instances. This ties patterns to the subtypes within PolicyLine entities, ensuring that each product is accurately represented and configured within the system.
slides.ocrText:
| PolicyLine subtypes Gi

BusinessAutoLine BicycleLine
PolicyLine
subtype

slides.title: Details for Policy Lines
slides.originalNotes:
Details for policy lines
This slide shows only a few of many features of a policy line to gather in order to configure the product model's policy line. Other examples of features for a Commercial Property Line include: 1) a location-attached coverables (a location that has a coverage), 2) building-attached coverables (A building that has coverages), 3) exclusions attached to coverables (the coverables you want to support exclusions being attached to). Not every feature is included for every business requirement.
slides.notes:
Details for policy lines
This slide shows only a few of many features of a policy line to gather in order to configure the product model's policy line. Other examples of features for a Commercial Property Line include: 1) a location-attached coverables (a location that has a coverage), 2) building-attached coverables (A building that has coverages), 3) exclusions attached to coverables (the coverables you want to support exclusions being attached to). Not every feature is included for every business requirement.
slides.narration: Policy lines are rich in features that need to be configured, such as location-attached and building-attached coverables. These features, including exclusions and modifiers, are tailored to meet diverse business requirements. This customization capability is key to developing products that align with specific insurance needs.

slides.title: Products
slides.originalNotes:
Products
After the Policy Line is defined, the product becomes easier to define. Insurers or agents sell products, such as personal auto or workers' compensation policies, to customers. Each individual policy that is sold is an instance of a product in PolicyCenter.
slides.notes:
Products
After the Policy Line is defined, the product becomes easier to define. Insurers or agents sell products, such as personal auto or workers' compensation policies, to customers. Each individual policy that is sold is an instance of a product in PolicyCenter.
slides.narration: After defining a policy line, configuring the actual product becomes much more straightforward. Products, such as personal auto or workers' compensation policies, are essentially instances of these predefined lines within PolicyCenter. This relationship underscores the importance of a well-structured policy line.

slides.title: Defining Product Attributes
slides.notes: Understand the attributes that define a product, from basic details to specific coverages and exclusions.
slides.narration: Defining a product involves specifying various attributes, from basic details to specific coverages and exclusions. This meticulous definition process is crucial for creating precise and effective insurance products tailored to market demands.

slides.title: Designing Your Product — What is Required
slides.originalNotes:
Designing your product — what is required
If you are a business analyst, you may be asked to design a new product for your PolicyCenter configuration If you are a developer, you will implement the requirements for a product This slide gives an example of what types of questions you ask during the design process. It is not exhaustive, but does cover important aspects that the product model requires. This example is based on a commercial property product. This information is all configurable using the product model tool, Product Designer.
slides.notes:
Designing your product — what is required
If you are a business analyst, you may be asked to design a new product for your PolicyCenter configuration If you are a developer, you will implement the requirements for a product This slide gives an example of what types of questions you ask during the design process. It is not exhaustive, but does cover important aspects that the product model requires. This example is based on a commercial property product. This information is all configurable using the product model tool, Product Designer.
slides.narration: When designing a product, business analysts focus on conceptualizing new offerings while developers implement these requirements. The design process involves addressing key questions about the product's structure, especially for commercial property products. Utilizing the Product Designer tool, these elements are configured to meet business objectives.

slides.title: Customizing Product Offerings
slides.notes: Customization is key to meeting diverse insurance needs. Learn how to tailor products with unique attributes.
slides.narration: Customization is at the heart of creating effective insurance products. By tailoring products with unique attributes, developers ensure that offerings meet diverse and specific insurance needs. This flexibility is vital for staying competitive in the insurance market.

slides.notes: Review practical implementation scenarios to understand how products and policy lines work in real-world contexts.

Question
A set of "legal and binding" information about the product is described
where?
Gi

questionData.question: A set of "legal and binding" information about the product is described where?
questionData.answer: In the policy line (the PolicyLine pattern).

slides.title: Data Model Considerations
slides.notes: Considerations for the data model when configuring products, focusing on entity relationships and data flow.
slides.narration: When configuring products, it's important to consider the data model, focusing on entity relationships and data flow. These considerations ensure that the product model is both effective and efficient, supporting the full range of insurance operations.
slides.ocrText:
Question
Although products are the first level of hierarchy in the product model,
what should you set up before you set up products?
Gi

questionData.question: Although products are the first level of hierarchy in the product model, what should you set up before you set up products?
questionData.answer: Although products are at the top of the hierarchy, products must be associated with at least one policy line and therefore policy lines must be configured before you configure a product for the product model.

slides.title: Troubleshooting Common Issues
slides.notes: Learn about common issues encountered during product configuration and how to resolve them effectively.
slides.narration: Let's talk about troubleshooting common issues you might encounter during product configuration. Understanding these potential pitfalls and their resolutions can save significant time and effort, ensuring a smoother development process.
slides.ocrText:
Answer Gi
Although products are the first level of hierarchy in the product model,
what should you set up before you set up products?
Although products are at the top of the hierarchy, products must be associated with at
least one policy line and therefore policy lines must be configured before you configure
a product for the product model.

slides.title: Best Practices in Product Configuration
slides.notes: Explore best practices for configuring products in PolicyCenter, focusing on efficiency, scalability, and maintainability.
slides.narration: Exploring best practices for configuring products in PolicyCenter is crucial for achieving efficiency, scalability, and maintainability. These guidelines help ensure that your configurations are robust and adaptable to future changes and expansions.
slides.ocrText:
Question
Can a single product having multiple policy line patterns exist? Give an
example.
•
Gi

questionData.question: Can a single product having multiple policy line patterns exist? Give an example.
questionData.answer: A package can have a single product that includes multiple policy line patterns. The base configuration includes a Commercial Package product that includes three policy lines: General Liability, Commercial Property, and Inland Marine.

Can a single product having multiple policy line patterns exist? Give an

•
A package can have a single product that includes multiple policy line patterns.
The base configuration includes a Commercial Package product that includes three
policy lines: General Liability, Commercial Property, and Inland Marine.
